These jars don't actually exist, but the sun.boot.class.path property claims 
they do (when we create the libs for a JRE). So, we add them to the source 
lookup path.

I'm getting this with build i0519-0010.

- I have all of Core loaded as source from the repo
- I opened the Plug-ins view and selected all and hit Add to Java Search
- I opened a CVS class file and added a breakpoint to it
- ran a runtime workbench

When I hit the breakpoint, it opened up a new editor without the source and I
got the same stack as Darin. The interesting thing to note was that the right
editor was already open but wasn't recognized by the debugger. (read: didn't
have the highlighted line, etc etc)

This is happening both on WinXP and Linux-GTK.

I should also have noted that my Target Platform is set to be the default.

What happens if your delete/re-add your VM install. It looks like our code 
accounts for libs that do not exist, but if you have an old workspace, it 
might not be working properly.

My first attempt at reproducing this with today's integration build was
unsuccessful. I can't remember the exact case that I had last week but I will
try later.

Yes, I'm using an old workspace. (probably close to 4 years old)

I haven't been able to reproduce this in a clean workspace. Marking as WORKSFORME. 
Please reopen if this is still a problem.

Reopening as this can be reproduced with a new workspace using I20040529:
1. Start new workspace on JDK 1.4.2_04
2. Check out v_436 of org.eclipse.jdt.core from dev.eclipse.org
3. Open Java Perspective
4. Open ReconcileWorkingCopyOperation in Java editor
5. Add breakpoint at line 71
6. Debug->Run-time Workbench
7. In target workspace, create new Java Project 'Test' and new class 'X.java'
8. Edit X.java and save
9. You hit the breakpoint in the Debugger
10. Select variable 'problemRequestor'
11. Open Concrete Type Hierarchy
Observe: You get the exception above

There is no check to validate the existence of the JARs or directories that is 
returned from library detection (LibraryDetector) or anywhere else.

The later, directories, will not work correctly.  jre\classes is being wrapped 
with an ExternalSourceArchiveContainer regardless of whether the directory 
exists.

Fixed this problem in JRERuntimeClasspathEntryResolver. The resolver now only 
returns resolved libraries that exist in the file system. However, I have 
discovered a new bug while fixing this - open declared/concrete type hierarchy 
does not work for inner types (I will file a new bug for that).
